Entertainment Merchants Association and Entertainment Software Association |USVol = 564 |USPage = 786 | ParallelCitations = |Docket=08-1448 | OralArgument = | OralReargument = | OpinionAnnouncement = |Prior=Preliminary injunction granted to plaintiffs, sub nom. ''Video Software Dealers Assn. v. Schwarzenegger'', 401 [[Federal Supplement|F. Supp. 2d]] 1034 ([[United States District Court for the Northern District of California|N.D. Cal.]] 2005); summary judgment granted to plaintiffs, No. C-05-04188, 2007 [[Westlaw|WL]] 2261546 (N.D. Cal. Aug. 6, 2007); aff'd, 556 [[Federal Reporter|F. 3d]] 950 ([[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit|9th Cir.]] 2009);''[[certiorari|cert.]]'' granted, 559 U.S. 1092 (2010) | Subsequent = |Holding = Bans on the sale of violent video games to children without parental supervision violate the [[Free Speech Clause]] of the First Amendment. United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit affirmed. |SCOTUS=2010-2016 |Majority=Scalia |JoinMajority=Kennedy, Ginsburg, Sotomayor, Kagan |Concurrence=Alito |JoinConcurrence=Roberts | Concurrence2 = | JoinConcurrence2 = | Concurrence/Dissent = | JoinConcurrence/Dissent = |Dissent=Thomas | JoinDissent = |Dissent2=Breyer | JoinDissent2 = |LawsApplied = [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|U.S. Const. amend. I]]; [[California Civil Code|Cal. Civ. Code]] §§ 1746–1746.5 (2009) }} '''''Brown v. Entertainment Merchants Association''''', 564 U.S. 786 (2011), is a [[landmark case]] by the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] that struck down a 2005 [[California]] law banning the sale of certain violent [[video game]]s to children without parental supervision.{{Cite web |url=http://www.mediacoalition.org/VSDA-v.-Schwarzenegger- |title=Schwarzenegger v. EMA |year=2010 |accessdate=2010-10-02 |publisher=mediacoalition.org |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100614063916/http://www.mediacoalition.org/VSDA-v.-Schwarzenegger- |archivedate=2010-06-14 |df= }} In a 7–2 decision, the Court upheld the lower court decisions and nullified the law, ruling that video games were protected speech under the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] as other forms of media.{{cite web|url=https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/10pdf/08-1448.pdf|title=Schwarzenegger v. EMA|year=2011|accessdate=2011-06-27|publisher=supremecourt.gov|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629023005/http://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/10pdf/08-1448.pdf|archivedate=2011-06-29|df=}} The ruling was seen as a significant victory for the [[video game industry]]. Several of the Court's justices suggested that the issue might need to be re-examined in the future, considering the changing nature of video games and their continuously improving technology. == Background == {{Main|Video game controversy#Crime and violence|l1=Connection between video games and crime and violence}} Many video games, as early as 1976's ''[[Death Race (1976 game)|Death Race]]'',{{cite web | url = https://www.wired.com/gamelife/2007/10/how-protests-ag/ | title = How Protests Against Games Cause Them To Sell More Copies | first = Chris | last = Kohler | date = 2007-10-30 | accessdate = 2011-06-28 | work = [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110605001253/http://www.wired.com/gamelife/2007/10/how-protests-ag/ | archivedate = 2011-06-05 | df = }} incorporate some aspect of violence into the gameplay mechanic, such as killing an enemy with a weapon, using explosives to destroy a structure, or engaging in dangerous vehicle races. With modern technology, representations of such violence have become more realistic. This has led to concerns that minors who play such video games will be influenced by the violence, altering their real-life behavior. Academic studies have attempted to find a connection between violent video games and the rate of violence and crimes from those that play them; some have stated a connection exists,Anderson, C. A., & Bushman, B. J. (2001). Effects of violent video games on aggressive behavior, aggressive cognition, aggressive affect, physiological arousal, and prosocial behavior: A meta-analytic review of the scientific literature. Psychological Science, 12, 353–359
{{cite journal | last1 = Funk | first1 = Hagan | last2 = Schimming | first2 = Bullock | last3 = Buchman | first3 = Jackie| last4 = Myers | first4 = Wesley A.| year = 2002 | title = Aggression and psychopathology in adolescents with a preference for violent electronic games | url = | journal = Aggressive Behavior | volume = 28 | issue = 2| pages = 134–144 | doi = 10.1002/ab.90015 | last5 = Buchman | first5 = Debra D. | last6 = Myers | first6 = Melissa }}Gentile, D. A. & Anderson, C. A. (2003). Violent video games: The newest media violence hazard. In D. A. Gentile (Ed.), Media violence and children. Westport, CT: Praeger Publishing while others find no link between the matters.Grand Theft Childhood: The Surprising Truth About Violent Video Games, Lawrence Kutner PhD and Cheryl K. Olson ScD"Video Games and Real Life Aggression," Lillian Bensely and Juliet Van Eenwyk, Journal of Adolescent Health, vol. 29, 2001"Video Games and Health," Mark Griffiths, British Medical Journal vol. 331, 2005 Incidents such as the [[Columbine High School massacre]] in 1999 have heightened concerns of a potential connection between video games and violent actions.{{cite web| url = http://www.nais.org/publications/ismagazinearticle.cfm?ItemNumber=144264 | title = Lessons from Littleton (Part I)| accessdate = August 24, 2008| work = Independent School | publisher = [[National Association of Independent Schools]]| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120209120528/http://www.nais.org/publications/ismagazinearticle.cfm?ItemNumber=144264 | archivedate = 2012-02-09}}{{cite web|url=http://slashdot.org/articles/99/04/25/1438249_F.shtml |title=Voices From The Hellmouth |accessdate=August 24, 2008 |author="JonKatz" |date=April 26, 1999 |publisher=Slashdot |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821074326/http://slashdot.org/articles/99/04/25/1438249_F.shtml |archivedate=August 21, 2008 }} Accordingly, many concerned groups including politicians and parents have sought to enact regulatory controls of video games to prevent their sales to youth. Prior and during the ''Brown v.'' case, parties like the [[Entertainment Software Association]] (ESA) sought to overturn similar state laws that placed limits on the sales of violent video games to minors in Michigan{{cite news | url = https://www.usatoday.com/tech/gaming/2006-04-04-michigan-law_x.htm | title = Judge rules Michigan video game law is unconstitutional | work = [[USA Today]] | date= 2006-04-04 | accessdate = 2010-11-01 }} and Illinois.{{cite web | url = http://news.cnet.com/8301-10784_3-6139030-7.html | title = Court rejects Illinois video game law | first = Anne |last = Broache | date= 2006-11-26 | accessdate= 2010-11-01 | publisher = [[CNet]] }} The ESA won these cases, with the laws being found unconstitutional and overly restrictive of protected speech. These states did not further challenge the court rulings. The ESA similarly defeated a Louisiana bill in the 2006 ''[[Entertainment Software Association v. Foti]]'' case that would have attempted to ban sales of violent video games from minors. [[File:ESRBrating.PNG|thumb|left|A typical ESRB rating label will identify the appropriate age group and specific content descriptors for each rated game.]] To counteract these increasing complaints and attempts at legislation, the video game industry in the United States created the [[Entertainment Software Rating Board]] (ESRB) in 1994.{{cite web | url = https://www.usatoday.com/tech/gaming/2011-06-28-video-game-ratings_n.htm | title = Game industry put focus on ratings years ago | first = Mike | last = Snider | date = 2011-06-28 | accessdate = 2011-06-28 | work = [[USA Today]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110702035618/http://www.usatoday.com/tech/gaming/2011-06-28-video-game-ratings_n.htm | archivedate = 2011-07-02 | df = }} This was prompted by a 1993 congressional hearing over the violence in the video game ''[[Mortal Kombat]]'' and lack of consistent content ratings between publishers, with Congress threatening to pass legislation that would mandate a ratings system if the industry did not take its own steps. The industry reacted by forming the Interactive Digital Software Association, which would become the ESA, and establishing the ESRB. The ESRB, like the [[Motion Picture Association of America]]'s rating system, is a voluntary and self-regulated body that examines the content of video games as provided by the publisher before distribution, and given a rating describing the content within, generally classified from being all ages-appropriate to adult audiences only. Video game distributors are similarly bound by voluntary compliance to check the age of the purchaser against the rating of the game to prevent the sale of mature titles to younger players. Most stores prevent the sale of unrated games, so virtually every video game sold at retail in the United States is rated by the ESRB.{{cite web | url = http://www.esrb.org/ratings/faq.jsp#1 | title = ESRB Frequently Asked Questions | publisher = [[ESRB]] | accessdate = 2011-06-28 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110624103954/http://www.esrb.org/ratings/faq.jsp#1 | archivedate = 2011-06-24 | df = }} Attempts have been made to mandate the ratings system; the [[Family Entertainment Protection Act]], a 2005 bill introduced into the U.S. Congress by Senators [[Hillary Clinton]], [[Joseph Lieberman]], and [[Evan Bayh]], would have made ESRB participation mandatory with oversight by the Federal Trade Commission, and introduced fines for selling Mature or Adult-Only content to minors. The bill, however, did not clear the Senate. Though the ESRB met criticism in 2000–2005 for the ease of access of mature-rated games to minors, the Board has improved its efforts to enforce the ratings system at retailers. A 2011 report issued by the [[Federal Trade Commission]] found that the voluntary controls by the ESRB had the highest success rate of any media industry, preventing sales of mature titles to minors 87% of the time.{{Cite web | url = http://www.ftc.gov/opa/2011/04/violentkidsent.shtm | title = FTC Undercover Shopper Survey on Enforcement of Entertainment Ratings Finds Compliance Worst for Retailers of Music CDs and the Highest Among Video Game Sellers | date = 2011-04-20 | accessdate = 2011-06-28 | publisher = [[Federal Trade Commission]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110817072723/http://ftc.gov/opa/2011/04/violentkidsent.shtm | archivedate = 2011-08-17 | df = }} Similar content rating systems exist in other countries, including the [[British Board of Film Classification]], the [[Australian Classification Board]], and Japan's [[Computer Entertainment Rating Organization]]. == The California law == [[File:Leland Yee.jpg|right|thumb|upright|Former-California Senator [[Leland Yee]] introduced CA Law AB 1179, the law debated in the case.]] In 2005, the [[California State Legislature]] passed AB 1179, sponsored by then-[[California State Senator]] [[Leland Yee]], which banned the sale of violent video games to anyone under age 18 and required clear labeling beyond the existing ESRB rating system. The law would have a maximum $1000 fine for each infraction. The definition of "violent video game" used a variation of the [[Miller test]], a three-pronged test used previously by the [[United States Supreme Court]] to define when [[obscene]] speech is not protected under the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]].{{cite web | url = http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/6191/video_game_regulation_and_the_.php | title = Video Game Regulation and the Supreme Court: Schwarzenegger v. Entertainment Merchants Association | first = S. Gregory | last = Boyd | date = 2010-11-01 | accessdate = 2010-11-01 | publisher = [[Gamasutra]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101102225129/http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/6191/video_game_regulation_and_the_.php | archivedate = 2010-11-02 | df = }} The bill was signed into law by Gov. Schwarzenegger in October 2005.{{cite web |last=Hoffman |first=Gene |title=How the Wrong Decision in ''Schwarzenegger v. EMA'' Could Cripple Video Game Innovation |publisher=Xconomy.com |date=September 27, 2010 |accessdate=2010-09-27 |url=http://www.xconomy.com/san-francisco/2010/09/27/how-the-wrong-decision-in-schwarzenegger-v-ema-could-cripple-video-game-innovation/ |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100930150915/http://www.xconomy.com/san-francisco/2010/09/27/how-the-wrong-decision-in-schwarzenegger-v-ema-could-cripple-video-game-innovation/ |archivedate=September 30, 2010 |df= }} The law would have gone into effect in January 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/news/6135332.html |title=Schwarzenegger signs game-restriction bill |first=Tor |last=Thorsen |date=2005-10-07 |accessdate=2010-11-01 |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101029025003/http://www.gamespot.com/news/6135332.html |archivedate=2010-10-29 |df= }} The law was a second attempt by Senator Yee to enact restrictions for video game sales to minors. Yee's background as a [[child psychologist]] led him to assert there was a connection between video games and violence and believed that the government had strong interest in restricting video game sales to minors as was already done for pornographic works.{{Cite news | url = http://articles.latimes.com/2010/apr/29/business/la-fi-ct-facetime-20100429 | title = Lawmaker defends law banning sale of violent video games to minors | date = 2010-04-10 | accessdate = 2010-11-02 | first = Ben | last = Fritz | work = Los Angeles Times | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101031194737/http://articles.latimes.com/2010/apr/29/business/la-fi-ct-facetime-20100429 | archivedate = 2010-10-31 | df = }} In 2004, Yee had drafted a law that would have required mature-rated video games to be stocked separately from other titles. Though the bill ultimately passed as CA Law AB 1793, the bill's language was diluted at its passage, only requiring stores to display the ESRB ratings system and provide information to parents about it.{{Cite web | url = http://www.gamasutra.com/php-bin/news_index.php?story=4324 | title = Schwarzenegger Signs California Video Games Bill | publisher = [[Gamasutra]] | date = 2004-09-22 | accessdate = 2010-11-02 | first = David | last = Jenkins | first2 = Simon | last2 = Carless | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101109172729/http://www.gamasutra.com/php-bin/news_index.php?story=4324 | archivedate = 2010-11-09 | df = }} == Legal challenges == === The District Court opinion === Before the California bill was signed into law, the ESA and the Video Software Dealers Association (VSDA), now known as the [[Entertainment Merchants Association]] (EMA), were preparing a lawsuit to overturn the law, fearing that the "violent video game" definition would affect many titles that the ESRB has otherwise labeled appropriate for younger players, and threaten to harm the video game industry. The VSDA filed suit in the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of California]] and was later joined by the ESA. The two groups succeeded in obtaining a preliminary injunction in December 2005 to block enforcement of the law during the case; U.S. District Judge [[Ronald M. Whyte]] cited in his preliminary decision: "The plaintiffs have shown at least that serious questions are raised concerning the States' ability to restrict minors' First Amendment rights in connection with exposure to violent video games, including the question of whether there is a causal connection between access to such games and psychological or other harm to children."{{cite web | url = https://arstechnica.com/old/content/2005/12/5825.ars | title = California game law blocked | first = Ken | last = Fisher | date = 2005-12-22 | accessdate = 2010-11-01 | publisher = [[Ars Technica]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100812143845/http://arstechnica.com/old/content/2005/12/5825.ars | archivedate = 2010-08-12 | df = }} In August 2007, Whyte ultimately ruled for the plaintiffs, holding that the law violated the First Amendment, and that there was an insufficient showing of proof that either video games differed from other media or that there was established causality between violent video games and violent behavior.{{Cite court|litigants=Video Software Dealers Ass'n, et al. v. Schwarzenegger, et al. |vol=2007 |reporter=U.S. Dist. LEXIS |opinion=57472 |pinpoint= |court=N.D. Cal. |date=2007 |url= |quote=}} === The Ninth Circuit appeal === [[File:Arnold Schwarzenegger 2.jpg|thumb|upright|Then-Governor [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] led the appeal of the lower courts' decisions.]] California Governor [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] appealed the ruling in September 2007, stating that he would "vigorously defend this law" and that he and the people of California have "a responsibility to our kids and our communities to protect against the effects of games that depict ultra-violent actions."{{cite web | url = http://www.gamasutra.com/php-bin/news_index.php?story=15064 | title = Schwarzenegger To Appeal California Game Law Ruling | first = James | last = Dobson | date = 2007-08-10 | accessdate = 2010-11-01 | publisher = [[Gamasutra]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101111025315/http://www.gamasutra.com/php-bin/news_index.php?story=15064 | archivedate = 2010-11-11 | df = }} The [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit|Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals]] affirmed Whyte's decision in 2009.{{Cite court|litigants=Video Software Dealers Ass'n, et al. v. Schwarzenegger, et al. |vol=556 |reporter=F.3d |opinion=950 |pinpoint= |court=9th Cir. |date=2008 |url= |quote=}} The Ninth Circuit considered the constitutionality of the law; given the timeframe of the law's passing relative to litigation, it was referred to as the "Act" in the court's opinion. The Ninth Circuit affirmed the District Court's Summary Judgment for the VSDA by holding: #The Act is a presumptively invalid content-based restriction on speech, so it is subject to strict scrutiny and not the "variable obscenity" standard from ''Ginsberg v. New York''.{{cite court |litigants=Ginsberg v. New York |vol=390 |reporter=U.S. |opinion=629 |pinpoint= |court= |date=1968 |url=http://bulk.resource.org/courts.gov/c/US/390/390.US.629.47.html |quote=}} #The Act violates rights protected by the First Amendment because the state has not demonstrated a compelling interest, has not tailored the restriction to its alleged compelling interest, and there exists a less-restrictive means that would further the State's expressed interest.{{cite court |litigants=Video Software Dealers Ass'n v. Schwarzenegger |vol=556 |reporter=F.3d |opinion=950 |pinpoint= |court=9th Cir. |date=2009 |url=http://www.ca9.uscourts.gov/datastore/opinions/2009/02/20/0716620.pdf |quote=}} #The Act's labeling requirement is unconstitutionally compelled speech under the First Amendment because it does not require the disclosure of purely factual information, but compels the carrying of the State's controversial Opinion. The court first addressed the VSDA's argument that the entire Act should be invalidated based on the defendant's concession on appeal that the definition of "violent video game" in the Act is unconstitutionally broad. However, the statute had a [[severability clause]]California Civil Code § 1746.5. so the court went through the severability test set forth in ''Hotel Employees & Rest. Employees Int'l Union v. Davis''.{{cite court |litigants=Hotel Employees & Rest. Employees Int'l Union v. Superior Court |vol=35 |reporter=Cal. 4th |opinion=935 |pinpoint= |court= |date=2005 |url= |quote=}} The court held that the definition for "violent video game" is grammatically and functionally separable because, as an alternative definition of "violent video game," it can be removed from the Act without affecting the wording or function of the Act's other provisions. Further, the definitions are volitionally separable because those sections were not of critical importance to the passage of the Act and the legislative body would have adopted the Act had it foreseen the partial invalidation of the statute.{{cite court |litigants=Sonoma County Org. of Pub. Employees v. County of Sonoma |vol=23 |reporter=Cal. 3d |opinion=296 |pinpoint= |court= |date=1979 |url= |quote=}} These definition sections were only included to avoid the possibility that a court would rule the terms unconstitutionally vague; the court found that the legislature would still have enacted the statute without this definition section. The court next went on to determine what level of scrutiny should be applied in reviewing the Act's prohibitions. The defendants insisted that the "variable obscenity" standard from ''Ginsberg v. New York'' should be used. However, the court held that the "variable obscenity" standard does not apply to violence. The Court in ''Ginsberg'' was careful to place substantive limits on its holding, and concern in ''Ginsberg'' regarded only "sex material," not violence. The court declined to extend the application of the "variable obscenity" standard to violence, so strict scrutiny was applied instead. In applying the strict scrutiny standard, the court recognized that "content-based regulations are presumptively invalid,"{{cite court |litigants=R.A.V. v. City of St. Paul, Minnesota |vol=505 |reporter=U.S. |opinion=377 |pinpoint=382 |court= |date=1992 |url=http://bulk.resource.org/courts.gov/c/US/505/505.US.377.90-7675.html |quote=}} and to survive invalidation, the Act had to fulfill two qualifications: #Restrictions "must be narrowly tailored to promote a compelling Government interest." #"If a less restrictive alternative would serve the Government's purpose, the legislature must use that alternative."{{cite court |litigants=United States v. Playboy Entm't Group, Inc. |vol=529 |reporter=U.S. |opinion=803 |pinpoint=813 |court= |date=2000 |url=http://bulk.resource.org/courts.gov/c/US/529/529.US.803.html |quote=}} The court invalidated the statute on both accounts. First, the court said that in considering its decision, the court limited the purpose of the Act to the actual harm to the brain of a child playing a violent video game. As a result, the state was required to show that "the recited harms are real, not merely conjectural, and that the regulation will in fact alleviate these harms in a direct and material way."{{cite court |litigants=Turner Broad. Sys., Inc. v. FCC |vol=512 |reporter=U.S. |opinion=622 |pinpoint= |court= |date=1994 |url=http://bulk.resource.org/courts.gov/c/US/512/512.US.622.93-44.html |quote=}} Here, the defendants failed to do so because all of the reports they relied on in making these claims were admittedly flawed.Craig A. Anderson, ''An update on the effects of playing violate video games'', 27 J. Adolescence 113 (2004). {{cite web |url=http://inst.eecs.berkeley.edu/~cs10/fa09/dis/02/extra/update_violence.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-03-23 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110626065428/http://inst.eecs.berkeley.edu/~cs10/fa09/dis/02/extra/update_violence.pdf |archivedate=2011-06-26 |df= }}Douglas A. Gentile et al., ''The effects of violent video game habits on adolescent hostility, aggressive behaviors, and school performance'', 27 J. Adolescence 5 (2004).{{cite web |url=http://www.psychology.iastate.edu/faculty/caa/abstracts/2005-2009/05GA2.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-03-23 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719210915/http://www.psychology.iastate.edu/faculty/caa/abstracts/2005-2009/05GA2.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-19 |df= }}Jeanne B. Funk et al., ''Violence exposure in real-life, video games, television, movies, and the internet: is there desensitization?'', 27 J. Adolescence 23 (2004).{{cite web|url=http://www.lionlamb.org/research_articles/study%202.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-03-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110304042654/http://www.lionlamb.org/research_articles/study%202.pdf |archivedate=2011-03-04 |df= }} While the state is allowed to protect minors from actual psychological or neurological harm, it is not permitted to control minors' thoughts. Second, the court held that the defendants did not demonstrate the absence of less restrictive alternative means. In fact, video games already comply with a [[Entertainment Software Rating Board|voluntary rating system]] that rates video games based on their topics and age appropriateness. This is a clear example of a less restrictive means. The court noted that the least restrictive means is not the same as the most effective means. The court also evaluated the constitutionality of the Act's labeling provision, which requires that a label be affixed to the front of every package the state deems to be a "violent video game." Generally, "freedom of speech prohibits the government from telling people what they must say."{{cite court |litigants=Rumsfeld v. Forum for Academic and Institutional Rights, Inc. |vol=547 |reporter=U.S. |opinion=47 |pinpoint= |court= |date=2006 |url= |quote=}} However, the court has upheld compelled commercial speech where it is the inclusion of "purely factual and uncontroversial information" in advertising.{{cite court |litigants=Zaruder v. Office of Disciplinary Counsel |vol=471 |reporter=U.S. |opinion=626 |pinpoint= |court= |date=2985 |url=http://bulk.resource.org/courts.gov/c/US/471/471.US.626.83-2166.html |quote=}} However, the labeling requirement of "violent video game" is not factual information. The Act has not clearly and legally provided a way to determine if a video game is violent so the sticker does not convey factual information. Consequently, the court found that the Act is unconstitutional. === Supreme Court appeal === [[File:Hansel-and-gretel-rackham.jpg|thumb|upright|Justice Antonin Scalia, along with those supporting the ESA side of the case, questioned whether violent video games should be treated differently from other media with similar violence regularly exposed to minors, such as the fairy tale of [[Hansel and Gretel]].]] Gov. Schwarzenegger again appealed to the Supreme Court, looking to overturn the Ninth Circuit's ruling, filing a writ of ''[[certiorari]]'' to the Court in May 2009. The Supreme Court agreed to hear the case, at this point filed as ''Schwarzenegger v. Entertainment Merchants Ass'n.''{{cite news | url = https://www.usatoday.com/tech/gaming/2010-04-26-scotus-video-games_N.htm | title = High court takes video game case | work = [[USA Today]] | first = Joan | last = Biskupic | date = 2010-04-26 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101104071903/http://www.usatoday.com/tech/gaming/2010-04-26-scotus-video-games_N.htm | archivedate = 2010-11-04 | df = }} The fact that the Court accepted this case was considered surprising, based on the previous case record for such violent video game laws that were unanimously overturned in other states. Analysts believe that because the Court agreed to hear this case, there are unanswered questions between the protection of free speech from the First Amendment, and the legal enforcement of protecting minors from unprotected free speech such as through restrictions on the sales of pornography to minors.{{cite web | url = http://www.1up.com/news/supreme-court-review-california-violent | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150507185740/http://www.1up.com/news/supreme-court-review-california-violent | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 2015-05-07 | title = Supreme Court to Review California's Violent Videogame Law | first = Chris | last = Pereira | date = 2010-04-26 | accessdate = 2010-11-01 | publisher = [[1UP.com]] }} Just a week prior to the acceptance of the ''certiorari'', in ''[[United States v. Stevens]]'' the Court overturned another law that sought restrictions on depictions of animal cruelty, which some analysts felt would reflect the Court's position to likely overturn the violent video game law. The Entertainment Consumers Association (ECA) launched an online petition{{cite web |url=http://theeca.com/schwarzeneggervema |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-09-27 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100829081116/http://theeca.com/schwarzeneggervema |archivedate=2010-08-29 |df= }} along with their [[amicus brief]] to provide the Supreme Court additional information.{{cite web |last=Schramm |first=Mike |title=Violent video game case gets its date in Supreme Court on November 2 |publisher=Joystiq |date=August 27, 2010 |accessdate=2010-09-27 |url=http://www.joystiq.com/2010/08/27/violent-video-game-case-gets-its-date-in-supreme-court-on-nov-2/ |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100831100125/http://www.joystiq.com/2010/08/27/violent-video-game-case-gets-its-date-in-supreme-court-on-nov-2 |archivedate=August 31, 2010 |df= }} The [[Progress & Freedom Foundation]] and the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] together submitted an ''amicus'' brief citing social research that declared ''[[Super Mario Bros.]]'' to be a violent video game. It was compared to [[Mighty Mouse]] and [[Wile E. Coyote and Road Runner|Road Runner]], cartoons that depict a similar form of violence with little negative reaction from the public.{{Cite web |last=Schwarzenegger |first=Arnold |authorlink=Arnold Schwarzenegger |date=September 2010 |title=Brief of the Progress & Freedom Foundation and the Electronic Frontier Foundation as ''Amici Curiae'' in Support of Respondents |url=https://www.eff.org/files/filenode/schwarzenegger_v/EFFPFFamicus.pdf |accessdate=2010-10-05 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101009033941/http://www.eff.org/files/filenode/schwarzenegger_v/EFFPFFamicus.pdf |archivedate=2010-10-09 |df= }} Video game developers [[Microsoft]] and [[Activision Blizzard]] supported the ESA effort. Industry associations for musical works, movies, and publishing, including the [[National Association of Broadcasters]], the [[Motion Picture Association of America]], [[Recording Industry Association of America]], [[National Cable & Telecommunications Association]], and the [[Future of Music Coalition]], also submitted briefs to the court in favor of striking down the law, fearing that should the law found to be constitutional, their industries would also be affected.{{cite web | url = http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/30491/Major_Entertainment_Industry_Groups_Unite_Against_California_Video_Game_Law.php | title = Major Entertainment Industry Groups Unite Against California Video Game Law | first = Kris | last = Graft | date = 2010-09-17 | accessdate = 2010-11-02 | publisher = [[Gamasutra]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101107075608/http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/30491/Major_Entertainment_Industry_Groups_Unite_Against_California_Video_Game_Law.php | archivedate = 2010-11-07 | df = }} Associations for the protection of civil rights, including the [[American Civil Liberties Union]], the [[National Coalition Against Censorship]], and the [[National Youth Rights Association]], submitted ''amicus'' briefs.{{cite web|title=NYRA, ACLU & NCAC Brief in Video Game Case - .pdf |publisher=National Youth Rights Association |date=September 24, 2010 |accessdate=2011-01-25 |url=http://forums.youthrights.org/downloads.php?do=file&id=406/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722020332/http://forums.youthrights.org/downloads.php?do=file&id=406%2F |archivedate=July 22, 2011 }} Also filing amicus briefs against the State of California was a coalition of other states including Rhode Island, Arkansas, Georgia, Nebraska, North Dakota, Oklahoma, South Carolina, Utah and Washington, as well as Puerto Rico, which stated the law was unnecessary as no evidence linked video games to youth violence and the voluntary ESRB system was working well.{{cite web | format = Coalition of States, submitted ''amicus'' briefs | url = http://mediacoalition.org/mediaimages/Schwarzenegger%20v%20EMA_AG%20Amicus_09.17.10.pdf/ |title=Brief for Amici Curiae Rhode Island, Arkansas, Georgia, Nebraska, North Dakota, Oklahoma, Puerto Rico, South Carolina, Utah and Washington Supporting Respondents | publisher = mediacoalition.org | archivedate = 2012-05-30 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120530154314/http://mediacoalition.org/mediaimages/Schwarzenegger%20v%20EMA_AG%20Amicus_09.17.10.pdf}} Also submitting an amicus brief opposing the law was a coalition of 82 psychologists, criminologists, medical scientists and media researchers concerned that the State of California had misrepresented the science on video games.{{cite web | title = Social Science Brief, submitted ''amicus'' briefs | url = http://mediacoalition.org/mediaimages/Schwarzenegger%20v.%20EMA_Social%20Science%20Brief_09.17.10.pdf | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120425051156/http://mediacoalition.org/mediaimages/Schwarzenegger%20v.%20EMA_Social%20Science%20Brief_09.17.10.pdf | archivedate = 2012-04-25 | df = }} The State of California was joined by eleven other States, including those that had passed laws later declared unconstitutional; the States, in an ''amicus'' brief, stated that they are "vitally interested in protecting the welfare of children and in helping parents raise them" but the District Court's decision restricts their authority to do so.{{cite web | url = http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/29499/Eleven_States_Join_To_Support_California_Game_Legislation_In_Supreme_Court.php | title = Eleven States Join To Support California Game Legislation In Supreme Court | first = Chris | last = Remo | date = 2010-07-19 | accessdate = 2010-11-02 | publisher = [[Gamasutra]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101109033522/http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/29499/Eleven_States_Join_To_Support_California_Game_Legislation_In_Supreme_Court.php | archivedate = 2010-11-09 | df = }} Further supporting the State of California were the [[American Academy of Pediatrics]], the California Psychological Association, [[Common Sense Media]], and the [[Eagle Forum]].{{Cite web | url = http://www.scotusblog.com/case-files/cases/eanf/ | title = Schwarzenegger v. Entertainment Merchants Association | publisher = SCOTUS Blog | date = 2010-11-02 | accessdate = 2010-11-03 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101103020750/http://www.scotusblog.com/case-files/cases/eanf/ | archivedate = 2010-11-03 | df = }} [[Oral argument]]s were held on November 2, 2010. To California's attorney, the Justices voiced concern on the distinction between video games and other commercial works such as films and comic books. Justice [[Antonin Scalia]] wondered if the law with its vague definition of "violence" could also be applied to [[Grimm's Fairy Tales]]. To the ESA and other trade groups, the Justices suggested that California and other states do have precedence to protect minors from certain forms of violence, though under narrower terms than the California law.{{cite news | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704462704575590333558912068 | title = Court Voices Doubts on Violent Videogame Law | first = Brent | last = Kendall | date = 2010-11-02 | accessdate = 2010-11-02 | work = [[Wall Street Journal]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150724141900/http://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704462704575590333558912068 | archivedate = 2015-07-24 | df = }} Justice [[John Roberts]] argued that while companies can provide parental filters on such violent games, "any 13-year-old can bypass [them] in about five minutes." Several questions centered on the controversial game ''[[Postal 2]]'', where the player can urinate on non-player characters and set them ablaze, among other violent acts.{{cite web | url = http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/31316/Analysis_from_the_Supreme_Court_Schwarzenegger_v_EMA.php | title = Analysis: Inside The U.S. Supreme Court On 'Schwarzenegger v. EMA' | first = Chris | last = Morris | date = 2010-11-02 | accessdate = 2010-11-02 | publisher = [[Gamasutra]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101105070336/http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/31316/Analysis_from_the_Supreme_Court_Schwarzenegger_v_EMA.php | archivedate = 2010-11-05 | df = }} The Justices, in general, agreed that upholding California's law would require a "novel extension of First Amendment principles to expressions concerning violence."{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/03/us/03scotus.html | title = Supreme Court Debates Violent Video Game Ban | first = Adam | last = Liptak | authorlink = Adam Liptak | accessdate = 2010-11-02 | work = [[New York Times]] | date = 2010-11-02 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130928085651/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/03/us/03scotus.html | archivedate = 2013-09-28 | df = }} With [[Jerry Brown]] winning the [[California gubernatorial election, 2010|2010 California Governor election]], the case was renamed to ''Brown v. Entertainment Merchants Ass'n'' after the oral hearings.{{cite journal |last=Clements |first=Christopher |date=March 1, 2012 |title=Protecting Protected Speech: Violent Video Game Legislation Post-Brown v. Entertainment Merchants Ass'n |url=http://lawdigitalcommons.bc.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=3217&context=bclr |journal=[[Boston College Law Review]] |publisher=[[Boston College Law School]] |volume=53 |issue=2 |pages=661–692 |doi= |access-date=October 13, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161014064506/http://lawdigitalcommons.bc.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=3217&context=bclr |archivedate=October 14, 2016 |df= }} == Opinion == [[File:Antonin Scalia, SCOTUS photo portrait.jpg|thumb|upright|Justice [[Antonin Scalia]] wrote the majority opinion in the case.]] On June 27, 2011, the Supreme Court issued a 7–2 opinion striking down the California law as unconstitutional on the basis of the First and Fourteenth Amendments. The majority opinion was authored by Justice Antonin Scalia and joined by Justices Ginsburg, Kennedy, Sotomayor, and Kagan. It first held that "video games qualify for First Amendment protection": {{quote|Like the protected books, plays, and movies that preceded them, video games communicate ideas—and even social messages—through many familiar literary devices (such as characters, dialogue, plot, and music) and through features distinctive to the medium (such as the player's interaction with the virtual world). That suffices to confer First Amendment protection.}} Justice Scalia then affirmed that, while states may pass laws to block obscene material from minors as previously decided in the 1968 ''[[Ginsberg v. New York]]'' case, "speech about violence is not obscene," and California's statute was unlawful.{{cite web | url = https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2011/06/violent-video-games-scotus/ | title = States May Not Ban Sale, Rental of Violent Videogames to Minors | first = David | last = Kravits | date = 2011-06-27 | accessdate = 2011-06-27 | work = [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110629093204/http://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2011/06/violent-video-games-scotus/ | archivedate = 2011-06-29 | df = }} The decision pointed to fairy tales like those of the [[Brothers Grimm]], which are regularly given to children to read, "contain no shortage of gore" that are also present in video games. The decision further compared video games to classical works like ''[[The Divine Comedy]]'', stating that "Even if we can see in them nothing of any possible value to society..., they are as much entitled to the protection of free speech as the best of literature."{{Cite news | url = http://techland.time.com/2011/06/27/supreme-court-video-games-qualify-for-first-amendment-protection/ | title = Supreme Court: 'Video Games Qualify for First Amendment Protection' | first = Evan | last = Narcisse | date = 2011-06-27 | accessdate = 2011-06-27 | work = [[Time (magazine)|Time]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110629183606/http://techland.time.com/2011/06/27/supreme-court-video-games-qualify-for-first-amendment-protection/ | archivedate = 2011-06-29 | df = }} Scalia's decision also stated that the current self-moderated industry standards like the ESRB are operated effectively to regulate the sale of more mature games to minors, and that "filling the remaining modest gap in concerned-parents' control can hardly be a compelling state interest" requiring a law to enforce.{{cite web | url = http://ingame.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2011/06/27/6957472-1st-amendment-beats-ban-in-video-game-battle | title = 1st Amendment beats ban in video game battle | first = Stephen | last = Tolito | date = 2011-06-27 | accessdate = 2011-06-27 | publisher = [[MSNBC]] | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120118153215/http://ingame.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2011/06/27/6957472-1st-amendment-beats-ban-in-video-game-battle | archivedate=2012-01-18 }} The Court's decision also determined that from the evidence, there was no "compelling" link between violent video games and its effects on children.{{cite news | url = https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gazJYGtwgygMOKo0UkFFbt2IQ41g?docId=CNG.8685d6a6040541cc62b1b2322b148bc7.681 | title = Top US court zaps violent videogame sales ban | work = [[Agence France-Presse]] | date = 2011-06-27 | accessdate = 2011-06-27 }} The decision cited one medical report that asserted that cartoons like ''[[Looney Tunes]]'' generate the same effects in children as in games like ''[[Sonic the Hedgehog (series)|Sonic the Hedgehog]]'' or imagery of guns. === Alito's concurrence === Justice [[Samuel Alito]] wrote a separate [[concurring opinion|concurrence]] supporting the majority decision, and was joined by Chief Justice [[John Roberts]]. Though Alito agreed with the constitutional application to the California law, believing that its "threshold requirement" that guides what material would be covered by the law was too broad, he questioned the potential [[double standard]] that existed between violence and sexual content in regards to this threshold.{{Cite web | url = https://arstechnica.com/gaming/news/2011/06/puritans-and-lady-godiva-why-two-justices-voted-to-uphold-californias-video-game-law.ars | title = Puritans and Lady Godiva: why two justices voted to uphold California's video game law | first = Nate | last = Anderson | date = 2011-06-27 | accessdate = 2011-06-27 | publisher = [[Ars Technica]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110628215548/http://arstechnica.com/gaming/news/2011/06/puritans-and-lady-godiva-why-two-justices-voted-to-uphold-californias-video-game-law.ars | archivedate = 2011-06-28 | df = }} Alito wrote that he was unsure that there was no connection between violent video games and effects on children, stating that "There are reasons to suspect that the experience of playing violent video games just might be very different from reading a book, listening to the radio, or watching a movie or a television show," referencing the book '' Infinite Reality '' which highlights the psychological effects of virtual reality, and argued that the decision "would not squelch legislative efforts to deal with what is perceived by some to be a significant and developing social problem."{{Cite web | url = http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/35463/Supreme_Court_Decision_Alito_Expresses_Uncertainty_About_Violent_Games_Effects.php | title = Supreme Court Decision: Alito Expresses Uncertainty About Violent Games' Effects | first = Kris | last = Graft | date = 2011-06-27 | accessdate = 2011-06-27 | publisher = [[Gamasutra]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110702003152/http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/35463/Supreme_Court_Decision_Alito_Expresses_Uncertainty_About_Violent_Games_Effects.php | archivedate = 2011-07-02 | df = }} === Dissents === Justices [[Clarence Thomas]] and [[Stephen Breyer]] dissented, each authoring a separate dissent. Justice Thomas, in his dissent, considered that historically, the Founding Fathers "believed parents to have complete authority over their minor children and expected parents to direct the development of those children," and that the intent of the First Amendment "does not include a right to speak to minors (or a right of minors to access speech) without going through the minors' parents or guardians."{{Cite web | url = http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/35471/Supreme_Court_Decision_The_Dissenters_Side.php | title = Supreme Court Decision: The Dissenters' Side | first = Kris | last = Graft | date = 2011-06-27 | accessdate = 2011-06-27 | publisher = [[Gamasutra]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110629115001/http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/35471/Supreme_Court_Decision_The_Dissenters_Side.php | archivedate = 2011-06-29 | df = }} Breyer wrote separately, concerned that the majority's decision conflicts with previous rulings from ''Ginsberg'' and ''Miller''. He contrasted the previous findings regulating sales of publications containing nudity to those of violent video games: "But what sense does it make to forbid selling to a 13-year-old boy a magazine with an image of a nude woman, while protecting a sale to that 13 year-old of an interactive video game in which he actively, but virtually, binds and gags the woman, then tortures and kills her?" Breyer further argued that "This case is ultimately less about censorship than it is about education," believing that the Government has a vested interest in allowing parents to make decisions for their child as to "raise future generations committed cooperatively to making our system of government work," and that "California's law imposes no more than a modest restriction on expression."{{cite web | url = http://news.cnet.com/8301-31921_3-20074680-281/u.s-supreme-court-strikes-down-violent-video-game-law/ | title = U.S. Supreme Court strikes down violent video game law | first =Declan | last = McCullagh | date = 2011-06-27 | accessdate = 2011-06-27 | publisher = [[CNet]] }} Breyer also expressed concern that the self-regulation of the industry still allowed for 20% of minors to purchase mature video games on a national average, and as high as 50% in the case of one nationwide chain, based on the aforementioned 2011 [[Federal Trade Commission]] study. == Reactions == The ruling was praised by the video game industry, which had expected the law to be ruled unconstitutional, but sought affirmation by the Court. ESA's CEO, Michael Gallagher, responded that "The Court declared forcefully that content-based restrictions on games are unconstitutional; and that parents, not government bureaucrats, have the right to decide what is appropriate for their children."{{cite web | url = http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/35461/Video_Game_Industry_Celebrates_Supreme_Court_Victory.php | title = Video Game Industry Celebrates Supreme Court Victory | first = Frank | last = Cifaldi | date = 2011-06-27 | accessdate = 2011-06-27 | publisher = [[Gamasutra]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110630223419/http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/35461/Video_Game_Industry_Celebrates_Supreme_Court_Victory.php | archivedate = 2011-06-30 | df = }} Bo Anderson of the EMA stated that "there now can be no argument whether video games are entitled to the same protection as books, movies, music, and other expressive entertainment," while Electronic Arts' (former) CEO [[John Riccitiello]] asserted that the decision "affirmed the constitutional rights of game developers."{{cite web | url = https://www.forbes.com/feeds/ap/2011/06/27/business-technology-hardware-amp-equipment-us-video-games-sector-snap_8537172.html | title = Sector Snap: Game cos. cheer Supreme Court ruling | work = [[Associated Press]] | date = 2011-06-27 | accessdate =2011-06-27 }} Other entertainment industries, such as the Motion Picture Association of America, also showed support for the Court's decision. Former U.S. Senator and current head of the Association [[Chris Dodd]] recognized that the motion picture industry has seen similar attempts to limit its freedom of expression, and that "We applaud the Supreme Court for recognizing the far-reaching First-Amendment implications posed by the California law."{{cite web | url = http://popwatch.ew.com/2011/06/27/supreme-court-video-game-violence/ | title = Supreme Court rules against law restricting video game violence | work = [[Entertainment Weekly]] | first = Jeff | last = Labrecque | date = 2011-06-27 | accessdate = 2011-06-27 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110630082722/http://popwatch.ew.com/2011/06/27/supreme-court-video-game-violence/ | archivedate = 2011-06-30 | df = }} Groups that supported the California law were critical of the decision. California State Senator Leland Yee was very critical of the decision, claiming that "It is simply wrong that the video game industry can be allowed to put their profit margins over the rights of parents and the well-being of children."{{cite web | url = http://content.usatoday.com/communities/gamehunters/post/2011/06/author-of-violent-video-games-law-blasts-supreme-court-decision/1 | title = Author of violent video games law blasts Supreme Court decision | first = Brett | last = Molina | date = 2011-06-27 | accessdate = 2011-06-27 | work = [[USA Today]] }} Yee stated he would review the opinions and attempt to reintroduce a new bill within the constitutionality of the decision, and claimed it was "disappointing the court didn't understand just how violent these games are."{{cite news | url = https://www.forbes.com/feeds/ap/2011/06/27/entertainment-us-supreme-court-violent-video-games_8537064.html | title = Court overturns ban on video game sales to kids | first = Jesse | last = Holland | date = 2011-06-27 | accessdate =2011-06-27 | work = [[Forbes]] }} James Steyer of [[Common Sense Media]] also criticized the decision, citing that "If parents decide a violent game is okay for their kid, that's one thing, but millions of kids are not able to judge the impact of ultra-violence on their own."{{Cite web | url = http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/35473/Analysis_Despite_Ruling_Threats_Remain_For_The_Games_Industry.php | title = Analysis: Despite Ruling, Threats Remain For The Games Industry | first = Chris | last = Morris | date = 2011-06-27 | accessdate = 2011-06-27 | publisher = [[Gamasutra]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110629094614/http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/35473/Analysis_Despite_Ruling_Threats_Remain_For_The_Games_Industry.php | archivedate = 2011-06-29 | df = }} [[Andrew Schlafly|Andy Schlafly]], who had submitted a brief to the court on behalf of the Eagle Forum and Legal Defense Fund, heavily criticized the majority opinion, believing that "the court's latest disregard of parental rights is on a crash course with technological advances."{{cite web | url = https://www.usatoday.com/news/opinion/editorials/2011-06-27-Violent-videos-warp-young-minds_n.htm | title = Opposing view: Violent videos warp young minds | first = Andy | last = Schlafly | work = [[USA Today]] | date = 2011-06-27 | accessdate = 2011-06-27 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110701113428/http://www.usatoday.com/news/opinion/editorials/2011-06-27-Violent-videos-warp-young-minds_n.htm | archivedate = 2011-07-01 | df = }} Tim Winter of the [[Parents Television Council]] asserted that the Court's decision "replaces the authority of parents with the economic interests of the video game industry." The ''[[Washington Post]]'' opined that the California law "did nothing to infringe on the rights of adults" while dealing with "reasonable limitations on minors' access to extremely violent games that even the video game industry acknowledges are inappropriate," and that with the high bar for any future legislation, the onus is on the video game industry to maintain its self-policing of video game sales.{{Cite web | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/the-high-courts-misguided-decision-on-violent-video-games/2011/06/27/AGilYDoH_story.html | title = The high court's misguided decision on violent video games | work = [[Washington Post]] | date = 2011-06-27 | accessdate = 2011-06-27 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140327221239/http://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/the-high-courts-misguided-decision-on-violent-video-games/2011/06/27/AGilYDoH_story.html | archivedate = 2014-03-27 | df = }} Analysts believed that while this was a major victory for the video game industry, the challenge is not yet over. Dan Offner, a partner for the video game industry analysis firm Loeb & Loeb believed that similar laws and regulations will be sought by State and Federal governments, as "the regulation of mature content with respect to minors as a hot button issue for the Federal Trade Commission and the various state governments." Other analysts cited that as more game content becomes available online as opposed to retail channels, the focus may shift more towards "privacy and security" of children and preventing children from amassing large fees from pay-to-use gaming services, pointing to a $3 million settlement that [[Playdom]] had to pay for violating privacy of its younger users. Sean Bersell of the EMA noted that future debates over violent video games may involve public opinion in addition to new legislation, noting that "Retailers along with publishers and parents all have a role in keeping kids away from these games."{{cite web | url = http://www.pcworld.com/article/231288/violent_video_game_debate_where_do_we_go_from_here.html | title = Violent Video Game Debate: Where Do We Go From Here? | first = David | last = Daw | date = 2011-06-27 | accessdate = 2011-06-27 | work = [[PC World (magazine)|PC World]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110628215655/http://www.pcworld.com/article/231288/violent_video_game_debate_where_do_we_go_from_here.html | archivedate = 2011-06-28 | df = }} Seth Schiesel of the ''[[New York Times]]'' proposed that the Court's decision should be a challenge to the industry to show that they can mature on the decision that [[video games as an art form|video games are a form of art]], questioning the industry "Will you use it as cover to pump out schlock or will you rise to the opportunity and respectability that has been afforded you?"{{cite web | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/29/arts/video-games/what-supreme-court-ruling-on-video-games-means.html | title = Supreme Court Has Ruled; Now Games Have a Duty | work = [[New York Times]] | first = Seth | last = Schiesel | date = 2011-06-28 | accessdate = 2011-06-28 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110701202527/http://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/29/arts/video-games/what-supreme-court-ruling-on-video-games-means.html | archivedate = 2011-07-01 | df = }} Schiesel also considered that even if games with increased interactivity and reality may make the games more dangerous, this could also make the player more aware of the potential consequences of his or her actions, even when such an action is made with the purpose to gain points/level or to kill a "dangerous enemy" in that game. In January 2012, the state of California agreed to pay the ESA $950,000 for reimbursing the ESA's legal fees during the Supreme Court trial, atop approximately $350,000 in fees from the previous trials at lower courts. The ESA stated that it will use an unspecified portion of this money to help create after-school programs in "underserved" communities in the Oakland and Sacramento areas to help teach students job skills.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/news/california-paying-950000-for-failed-supreme-court-fight-6349243 |title=California paying $950,000 for failed Supreme Court fight |date=2012-01-26 |accessdate=2012-01-26 |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |first=Eddie |last=Makuch |first2=Brendan |last2=Sinclair |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120206095142/http://www.gamespot.com/news/california-paying-950000-for-failed-supreme-court-fight-6349243 |archivedate=2012-02-06 }} The total cost of defending the case is estimated around $1.8 million, including the State's own legal costs.{{cite news|url=http://www.sacbee.com/2012/02/19/4274796/failed-legal-fight-over-video.html |title=Failed legal fight over video games costs California nearly $2 million |first=Jim |last=Sanders |date=2012-02-22 |accessdate=2012-02-22 |work=[[Sacramento Bee]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120222015544/http://www.sacbee.com/2012/02/19/4274796/failed-legal-fight-over-video.html |archivedate=2012-02-22 }} In March 2012, Kenneth Doroshow and Paul M. Smith, the lawyers for the EMA who argued the case, were presented with the Ambassador Award by the [[International Game Developers Association]] [[Game Developers Choice Awards]]. The Ambassador Award "honors an individual or individuals who have helped the game industry advance to a better place, either through facilitating a better game community from within, or by reaching outside the industry to be an advocate for video games".{{Cite web | last = | first = | title = Game Developers Choice Online Awards – Ambassador Award Archive | url = http://www.gamechoiceawards.com/archive/ambassador.html | publisher = UBM Tech | date = March 2012 | accessdate = November 16, 2012 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130202090125/http://www.gamechoiceawards.com/archive/ambassador.html | archivedate = February 2, 2013 | df = }} In a seminar given in November 2014, Justice [[Elena Kagan]] expressed her thoughts on the decision in this case, noting that for herself, she faced a difficult decision between what she felt was right – allowing parents to decide what their children should watch and play – and what the state of the law was, and in hindsight, was still not sure if they made the right decision. She noted that she along with four others on the court effectively added language to the decision that would preempt any future laws that attempted to restrict game sales.{{Cite web | url = https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2015/01/supreme-court-justice-second-guesses-decisive-vote-in-gaming-free-speech-case/ | title = Supreme Court justice second-guesses decisive vote in gaming free speech case | first = Kyle | last = Orland | date = 2015-01-08 | accessdate = 2015-01-08 | publisher = [[Ars Technica]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150108044005/http://arstechnica.com/gaming/2015/01/supreme-court-justice-second-guesses-decisive-vote-in-gaming-free-speech-case/ | archivedate = 2015-01-08 | df = }} Mike Gallagher, CEO of the ESA, observed in 2017 that the same [[moral panic]] that led to concerns over video games and resulting in this case were starting to appear for newer video game systems that can further blur lines between the virtual and real world, such as [[virtual reality]], [[augmented reality]], and [[mixed reality]], and anticipates that there will be further tests of the applicability of First Amendment protection these new forms of media.{{cite web | url = https://venturebeat.com/2017/05/02/gaming-beat-the-supreme-court-now-its-time-to-defend-ar-and-vr/ | title = Gaming beat the Supreme Court — now it's time to defend AR and VR | first = Jeff | last = Grubb | date = May 2, 2017 | accessdate = May 2, 2017 | work = [[Venture Beat]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170503002612/https://venturebeat.com/2017/05/02/gaming-beat-the-supreme-court-now-its-time-to-defend-ar-and-vr/ | archivedate = May 3, 2017 | df = }} === Public opinion === A national telephone poll conducted in the second quarter of 2011 by [[Fairleigh Dickinson University]]'s [[Fairleigh Dickinson University#PublicMind|PublicMind]] showed that a majority of American voters (57%) agreed that states should have the "right to regulate the sale of video games [that are violent] in order to protect minors; the same way states regulate tobacco, alcohol and pornography." On the other hand, 39% of voters agreed with the Court's majority that "parents should make the decision" about what video games they purchase for their children, and what constitutes "too violent." These voters agreed with the statement "states do not have the right to decide that some video games are too violent for [minors], any more than they have the right to decide what literature or fairy tales are too violent." The poll was conducted before the Court released its decision on June 27, 2011.Fairleigh Dickinson University's PublicMind, (June 6, 2011). [http://publicmind.fdu.edu/2011/vmerchants/ “U.S. Public Says Regulate Violent Video Games, the Focus of Brown v. Entertainment Merchants.”] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110805065902/http://publicmind.fdu.edu/2011/vmerchants/ |date=2011-08-05 }} [Press Release] June 6, 2011. Retrieved from {{cite web |url=http://publicmind.fdu.edu/2011/vmerchants/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-10-06 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110805065902/http://publicmind.fdu.edu/2011/vmerchants/ |archivedate=2011-08-05 |df= }}; See e.g. Maryam K. Ansari, [https://blogs.findlaw.com/supreme_court/2011/06/california-video-game-law-before-us-supreme-court.html “California Video Game Law Before U.S. Supreme Court.”] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110820212114/https://blogs.findlaw.com/supreme_court/2011/06/california-video-game-law-before-us-supreme-court.html |date=2011-08-20 }} FindLaw: For Legal Professionals. June 8, 2011. == See also == *[[Video gaming in the United States]] == References == {{reflist|30em}} == Further reading == *{{cite journal|last=Norris |first=Robert Bryan, Jr. |year=2011 |title=It's All Fun and Games Until Someone Gets Hurt: ''Brown v. Entertainment Merchants Association'' and the Probleme of Interactivity |journal=North Carolina Journal of Law & Technology |volume=13 |issue= |pages=81–116 |url=http://www.ncjolt.org/sites/default/files/Norris_Final_81_116.pdf }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *{{cite journal |title=Do Violent Video Games Harm Children? Comparing the Scientific Amicus Curiae 'Experts' in ''Brown v. Entertainment Merchants Association'' |first=Deana |last=Pollard-Sacks |first2=Brad J. |last2=Bushman |first3=Craig A. |last3=Anderson |journal=Northwestern University Law Review Colloquy |volume=106 |issue= |pages=1 |year=2011 |ssrn=1856116 }} *{{cite journal |title=Sex, Lies, and Videogames: ''Brown v. Entertainment Merchants Association'' |first=David G. |last=Post |work=Temple University Legal Studies Research Paper No. 2012-03 |year=2012 |ssrn=1937639 }} *{{cite journal | title = Electronic Games and the First Amendment: Free Speech Protection for New Media in the 21st Century | first = Thomas | last = Rousse | journal = Northwestern Interdisciplinary Law Review | volume = 4 | issue = 1 | year = 2011 | pages = 173–233 | ssrn = 1868759 }} == External links == *[https://www.supremecourt.gov/Search.aspx?FileName=/docketfiles/08-1448.htm Supreme Court of the United States: docket for ''Brown v. {{Infobox company | name = Capital City Distribution | logo = | foundation = {{Start date and age|1980| | }} in [[Madison, Wisconsin]], U.S. | founder = [[Milton Griepp]], John Davis | defunct = {{End date|1996| | }} | key_people = Griepp, Davis, [[Richard Bruning]] | fate = Acquisition by [[Diamond Comic Distributors]] | location = [[Madison, Wisconsin]] | industry = [[Comics]] | revenue = $150 million | revenue_year = 1996 | subsid = Capital Comics | homepage = }} '''Capital City Distribution''' was a [[Madison, Wisconsin]]-based [[comic book]] [[direct market|distributor]] which operated from 1980 to 1996 when they were acquired by rival [[Diamond Comic Distributors]]. Under the name '''Capital Comics''', they also published comics from 1981 to 1984.
During most of its years of operation, Capital City introduced many supply chain innovations and controlled much of the American [[Midwest]]'s comics distribution market. More so than their rivals Diamond and [[Heroes World Distribution]], Capital City supported independent publishers as much as big mainstream companies like [[DC Comics]] and [[Marvel Comics]].<ref>MacDonald, Heidi. [http://www.comicsbeat.com/the-unbeleivable-world-of-80s-comics-sales/ "The unbelievable world of 80s comics sales,"] ''The Beat'' (12/01/2014).</ref>
Capital City also published over 400 pages of printed material a month, including ''Internal Correspondence'', which provided sales figures to their clients; and ''Advance Comics'',<ref name="ICv2" /> their monthly catalog showcasing upcoming comic books, toys, and other pop-culture related items it distributed to comic book specialty shops.
== Distributor ==
=== Origins === In the 1970s, [[Milton Griepp]] and John Davis were running a small Madison-based distributor called [[Wisconsin Independent News Distributors]] (WIND). Forced to sell their assets to [[Big Rapids Distribution]], Griepp and Davis later turned the tables in 1980 when they took over much of Big Rapids' bankrupt business to form Capital City.<ref name="ICv2" /><ref name=Booker>Booker, M. Keith, editor. ''Comics through Time: A History of Icons, Idols, and Ideas'' (ABC-CLIO, 2014), p. 929.</ref>
One of Capital City's first acts was to utilize the personnel of another former Big Rapids' acquisition, [[Well News Co.]] of Columbus, Ohio, to become the nucleus of an early distribution branch. In 1982, Capital City acquired the Berkeley, California-based [[Common Ground Distributors]], which had been started by [[Robert Beerbohm]] in the late 1970s (and had been initially supplied by Big Rapids).
Capital City's Wisconsin location was relatively near [[World Color Press]]'s main printing plant in [[Sparta, Illinois]]. (During that period World Color printed most American comic books, including those of the two industry giants [[Marvel Comics|Marvel]] and [[DC Comics|DC]].)<ref name="KC">Carlson, KC. [http://westfieldcomics.com/blog/interviews-and-columns/kc-column-scaling-mount-baron/ "KC Column: Scaling Mount Baron,"] Westfield Comics (Nov. 16, 2009).</ref> By 1982, Capital City operated out of a large warehouse in Madison that they shared with their largest account, [[mail-order]] retailer [[Westfield Comics]].<ref name="KC" /><ref name=Booker />
=== 1984 expansion and rise to prominence === Griepp became Capital City's CEO in 1984.<ref name="ICv2" /> That same year, with the demise of one of the larger independent publisher/distributors, [[Pacific Comics]], Pacific's distribution centers and warehouses were purchased by Capital City and rival distributor [[Bud Plant Inc.]] Capital City also opened an expanded facility in [[Sparta, Illinois]], in the old space of another defunct rival, [[Sea Gate Distributors]], alongside the comic-book printing plant.<ref name="Sanford"/>
By 1988, Capital City and its main surviving rival [[Diamond Comics Distributors]] had control of at least 70% of the comics distribution market between them.
In 1994, Capital created controversy by announcing penalties for publishers who didn't deliver their products within promised deadlines; this move followed an industry-wide push for 30-day returnability, a practice formerly in use when comics were primarily distributed in newsstands.<ref>"Newswatch: Capital Announces Controversial Penalty Fees for Publishers: Move Follows Industry-wide Push for 30-day Returnability," ''The Comics Journal'' #166 (February 1994), pp. 17–26.</ref>
By this point, Capital City's Canadian affiliate, STV, had warehouses in Toronto, Montreal, and Quebec City; and Capital City had another freight forwarder operating out of Seattle, Washington.{{cn|date=October 2018}}
=== Acquisition by Diamond === 1995 saw a major restructuring of the direct market distribution system, caused by [[Marvel Comics]]'s late-1994 purchase of third-ranked distributor [[Heroes World Distribution]] and decision to distribute its titles in-house.<ref name="DuinCC">Duin, Steve and [[Mike Richardson (publisher)|Richardson, Mike]] (ed.s) "Capital City" in ''Comics Between the Panels'' ([[Dark Horse Comics|Dark Horse Publishing]], 1998) {{ISBN|1-56971-344-8}}, p. 69</ref><ref>"Marvelutionary War Declared: Unprecedented Upheaval in Direct Market," ''The Comics Journal'' #175 (March 1995), pp. 9-10.</ref> Faced with the loss of one-third of its business (Marvel's market share) Diamond reacted by outbidding Capital City for exclusive deals with Marvel's main rival [[DC Comics]]; and despite intense efforts on the part of Davis and Griepp,<ref>Rozanski, Chuck. [http://www.milehighcomics.com/tales/cbg131.html "Tales From the Database: Diamond Ended Up With 50% of the Comics Market,"] Mile High Comics (2004).</ref> [[Dark Horse Comics]] and [[Image Comics]] as well.
Capital City reacted by suing Marvel for the loss of their business, resulting in a settlement allowing them to continue distributing Marvel product until October 1995<ref>"Marvel goes exclusive, Capital sues Marvel, Marvel settles with Capital, Marvel buys Skybox, DC/Diamond announcement expected," ''The Comics Journal'' #175 (March 1995), pp. 9-10.</ref> (for everyone else, Marvel went exclusive with Heroes World starting in July).<ref>Miller, John Jackson. [http://www.comichron.com/monthlycomicssales/1995.html "1995 Comic Book Sales Figures: Comics Preordered by North American Comics Shops as Reported by Capital City Distribution and Diamond Comic Distributors"], The Comics Chronicles.</ref> In addition, Capital City was able to sign exclusive deals with [[Kitchen Sink Press]], [[TSR, Inc.|TSR]], and [[Viz Comics]]—as well as acquiring the Gary, Indiana-based distributor [[Friendly Frank's]].<ref>"Newswatch: Capital City Acquires Friendly Frank's," ''The Comics Journal'' #178 (July 1995), pp. 13-15.</ref> Nonetheless, by 1996 Capital faced the choice between bankruptcy and selling out.
In July 1996 Capital City was acquired by Diamond. At the time of sale, Capital had over $150 million in annual sales.<ref name="ICv2">[http://icv2.com/about/ "Who We Are: Milton Griepp," ICv2.com.] Accessed October 15, 2009.</ref> The purchase price was not disclosed, but the acquisition brought an estimated $50 million in sales revenue to Diamond,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0EIN/is_1996_July_26/ai_18526328|title=FindArticles.com {{!}} CBSi|website=findarticles.com|access-date=2016-09-23}}</ref> and effectively awarded Diamond complete control of the comics distribution system.<ref name="DuinCC"/> Most of Capital City's 100 employees in Madison and another 100 in Sparta lost their jobs in the deal,<ref>Daykin, Tom. "Comic book distributor to fold: Battered by competitive forces, Capital City Distribution sells assets," ''Milwaukee Journal Sentinel'' (July 27, 1996).</ref> though a few key staff members, including co-founder John Davis, joined Diamond's staff.<ref>"Davis and Former Capital City Employees Join Diamond," ''The Comics Journal'' #192 (Dec. 1996), pp. 13-15.</ref>
After selling Capital, Griepp became an industry consultant, and since early 2001, has operated [[ICv2]] ("''Internal Correspondence'' vol. 2"), an online trade magazine covering "[[geek culture]]."<ref name="ICv2" />
== Publisher == In 1981, Capital City decided to enter the comic book publishing field as well. Under the name '''Capital Comics''', they launched a black-and-white comics title, ''[[Nexus (comics)|Nexus]]'', a futuristic superhero series by [[Mike Baron]] and [[Steve Rude]], and distributed it through their own system.<ref name="Sanford">Sanford, Jay Allen. [http://www.sandiegoreader.com/news/2004/aug/19/two-men-and-their-comic-books/ "Two Men and their Comic Books]," ''[[San Diego Reader]]'' (Aug. 19, 2004).</ref>
[[Richard Bruning]] was a key part of Capital Comics' staff, acting as Editor-In-Chief and Art Director until the company ceased operation in 1984. Besides ''Nexus'', the other titles published by Capital were ''[[Badger (comics)|Badger]]'' and ''[[Whisper (comics)|Whisper]]''. In 1984, after publishing only a handful of issues of their three titles, Capital shut down its publishing operation.<ref>"Capital Comics Suspends Operations," ''The Comics Journal'' #89 (May 1984), pp. 8-9.</ref> Its titles were taken over by the new independent publisher [[First Comics]].
=== Titles published === * ''Nexus'': two series, 1981 and 1983, nine issues * ''Badger'': 1983, four issues * ''Whisper'': 1983, two issues
==See also== * [[List of book distributors]]

{{Spanish name|Sánchez|Ferlosio}}
'''José Antonio Julio Onésimo Sánchez Ferlosio''', better known as '''Chicho Sánchez Ferlosio''' ([[Madrid]], April 8, 1940 - July 1, 2003), was a [[Spain|Spanish]] [[singer-songwriter]], and the author of numerous songs performed by other artists, such as [[Rolando Alarcón]], [[Joan Baez]], [[Soledad Bravo]], [[Víctor Jara]], [[Quilapayún]] and [[Joaquín Sabina]].
He was the son of the writer and founding member of the [[Falange]], [[Rafael Sánchez Mazas]], brother of the writer [[Rafael Sánchez Ferlosio]] and the mathematician and philosopher Miguel Sánchez Ferlosio.
== Politics ==
Though his father was one of the founding member of the fascist Falange, Ferlosio was a leftist militant whose politics gradually moved further away from [[Stalinism]] and orthodox leftism towards anarchism following the death of [[Francisco Franco|Franco]]. He was first a militant in the [[Communist Party of Spain|Partido Comunista de España]], but after visiting the [[People's Socialist Republic of Albania]] and seeing the repressive and hypocritical government there, as well as becoming influenced by his friend the poet [[Agustín García Calvo]], he turned away from all forms of communism and considered himself an anarchist. His new stance could be summed up in his belief that "ideas are for men, and not men for ideas".
== Discography ==
Ferlosio, a prolific composer, only recorded a small part of his repertoire. His official discography includes only one LP ''A Contratiempo''. However, many artists have adapted his songs.
== External links == * [http://www.chichosanchezferlosio.es/ Canciones de la resistencia española]. 1964. Investigación sobre el disco sueco de Chicho Sánchez Ferlosio. * [http://www.portaldepoesia.com/Textos_poetas/Jesus_Munarriz_ChichoSanchezFerlosio.htm Fotografía de Chicho Sánchez Ferlosio] * [http://www.clubcultura.com/clubcine/clubcineastas/trueba/cuerpo1.htm Hasta que el cuerpo aguante] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C7cN0qV60zc Romancero de Durruti]

[[File:Amalfi - 7332.jpg|thumb|300px|right|A couple posing for wedding photos on the steps of a church in Italy]]
Marriage is the legally or formally recognized intimate and complementing union of two people as spousal partners in a personal relationship (historically and in most jurisdictions specifically a union between a man and a woman).
The basic elements of a marriage are: (1) the parties' legal ability to marry each other, (2) mutual consent of the parties, and (3) a marriage contract as required by law.
In [[Christianity|Christian]] [[marriage]], the union between a man and a woman is instituted and ordained by [[God in Christianity|God]] as the lifelong relationship between one man as [[husband]], and one woman as [[wife]]. The Apostle Paul gave a similar directive when he wrote, "Let marriage be held in honour among all".{{Bibleref2c|Heb.|13:4}} Conservative Christians consider marriage as the [[eros|most intimate]] of human relationships, a gift from God, and a sacred institution.<ref>http://www.focusonthefamily.com/marriage/gods-design-for-marriage/honoring-marriage. Accessed 15 Jan. 2018</ref> [[Protestantism|Protestants]] consider it to be sacred, holy, and central to the community of faith. [[Catholic Church|Catholics]] and [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Eastern Orthodox Christians]] consider marriage a [[Sacrament]].
Though it is presumed that [[Jesus]] never married, He taught the importance and sacredness of lifelong marriage. He quoted from both Genesis 1 and 2{{Bibleref2c|Matthew|19:3-5|9}} that God had created humanity as male and female,{{Bibleref2c|Genesis|1:27|9}} and that in marriage "the two become one flesh".{{Bibleref2c|Genesis|2:24|9}} Then He added: "So they are no longer two, but one flesh. Therefore, what God has joined together, let no one separate".{{Bibleref2c|Matthew|19:6|9}}
While marriage is honored throughout the Bible and affirmed among Christians, there is no suggestion that it is necessary for everyone. Single people, who either have chosen to remain unmarried or who have [[Widowhood#Terminology|lost their spouse]], are neither incomplete in Christ nor personal failures.<ref name="Staggs">{{citation |last1=Stagg |first1=Evelyn |author1-link=Evelyn Stagg |first2=Frank |last2=Stagg |author2-link=Frank Stagg (theologian) |title=[[Woman in the World of Jesus]] |place=Philadelphia |publisher=Westminster |year=1978 |isbn=0-664-24195-6 }}</ref>
==Background== Christians seek to uphold the seriousness of wedding vows. Yet, they respond with compassion to deep hurts by recognizing that [[divorce]], though less than the ideal, is sometimes necessary to relieve one partner of intolerable hardship, unfaithfulness or desertion.<ref name="Staggs"/> While the voice of God had said, "I hate divorce",{{Bibleref2c|Malachi|2:16}} some authorities believe the divorce rate in the church is nearly comparable to that of the culture at large.<ref name=Desai>Amy Desai, J.D. [http://www.focusonthefamily.com/marriage/divorce_and_infidelity/should_i_get_a_divorce/how_should_a_christian_view_marriage_and_divorce.aspx How Should a Christian View Marriage and Divorce?] Accessed 15 Jan. 2018</ref>
Christians today hold three competing views as to what is the biblically-ordained relationship between husband and wife. These views range from [[Christian egalitarianism]] that interprets the New Testament as teaching complete ''equality of authority and responsibility'' between the man and woman in marriage, all the way to [[Patriarchy]] that calls for a “return to complete patriarchy” in which relationships are based on male-dominant power and authority in marriage:<ref name=Patriarchy/>
1. [[Christian egalitarianism|Christian Egalitarians]] believe in an equal partnership of the wife and husband with neither being designated as the leader in the marriage or family. Instead, the wife and husband share a fully ''equal partnership'' in both their marriage and in the family. Its proponents teach "the fundamental biblical principle of the equality of all human beings before God".
"There is neither Jew nor Gentile, neither slave nor free, nor is there male and female, for you are all one in Christ Jesus."{{Bibleref2c|Gal.|3:28}}
According to this principle, there can be no moral or theological justification for permanently granting or denying status, privilege, or prerogative solely on the basis of a person's race, class, or gender.<ref name=Groothuis>Groothuis, Rebecca M. "Sexuality, Spirituality and Feminist Religion".
